description: From Late Middle English droppe, Middle English drope (“small quantity of liquid; small or least amount of something; pendant jewel; dripping of a liquid; a shower; nasal flow, catarrh; speck, spot; blemish; disease causing spots on the skin”) [and other forms], from Old English dropa (“a drop”), from Proto-West Germanic *dropō (“drop (of liquid)”), from Proto-Germanic *drupô (“drop (of liquid)”), from Proto-Indo-European *dʰrewb- (“to crumble, grind”).

definitionGroups.group: (also figuratively) A small quantity of liquid, just large enough to hold its own round shape through surface tension, especially one that falls from a source of liquid.

entries.meaning: (pharmacology) A dose of liquid medicine in the form of a drop (sense 1).
(pharmacology, chiefly in the plural) A liquid medicine that is intended to be administered in drops (sense 1).
examples: ear drops    eye drops

definitionGroups.group: (figuratively) A very small quantity of liquid, or (by extension) of anything.

entries.meaning: (chiefly Australia, Britain) A small amount of an alcoholic beverage.
examples: He usually enjoys a drop after dinner.    She won’t touch a drop while she’s on duty.

entries.meaning: (chiefly Britain) Usually preceded by the: alcoholic spirits in general.
examples: It doesn’t matter where you’re from, anyone who enjoys the drop is a friend of mine.

entries.meaning: (Ireland, informal) A single measure of whisky.

definitionGroups.group: That which hangs or resembles a liquid globule, such as a hanging diamond earring or ornament, a glass pendant on a chandelier, etc.

entries.meaning: Often preceded by a defining word: a small, round piece of hard candy, such as a lemon drop; a lozenge.
(architecture) An ornament resembling a pendant; a gutta.

definitionGroups.group: A thing which drops or hangs down.

entries.meaning: The cover mounted on a swivel over a keyhole that rests over the keyhole when not in use to keep out debris, but is swiveled out of the way before inserting the key.
(agriculture) A fruit which has fallen off a tree, etc., or has been knocked off accidentally, rather than picked.
(American football) A dropped pass.
examples: Yet another drop for the Tiger tight end.

entries.meaning: (law enforcement) A trapdoor (“hinged platform”) on a gallows; a gallows itself.
(online gaming, video games) An item made available for the player to pick up from the remains of a defeated enemy.
(technology)
A mechanism for lowering something, such as a machine for lowering heavy weights on to a ship's deck, or a device for temporarily lowering a gas jet, etc.
Short for drop hammer and drop press.
(theater) A curtain which falls in front of a theatrical stage; also, a section of (cloth) scenery lowered on to the stage like a curtain.

definitionGroups.group: An act or instance of dropping (in all senses).

entries.meaning: An act of moving downwards under the force of gravity; a descent, a fall.
examples: That was a long drop, but fortunately I didn’t break any bones.

entries.meaning: An instance of making a delivery of people, supplies, or things, especially by parachute out of an aircraft (an airdrop), but also by truck, etc.
examples: The delivery driver has to make three more drops before lunch.
The spy made the drop, leaving the plans under the tree as arranged.

entries.meaning: A release (of music, a video game, etc).
(gambling) The amount of money that a gambler exchanges for chips in a casino.
(law enforcement, informal) Preceded by the: execution by hanging.
(sports)
examples: The Tiger quarterback took a one-step drop, expecting his tight end to be open.

entries.meaning: Usually preceded by the: relegation from one division to a lower one.
(American football) Short for drop-back.
examples: The Tiger quarterback took a one-step drop, expecting his tight end to be open.

entries.meaning: (pinball) Short for drop target.
(rugby) Short for drop kick.
(golf) Short for drop shot.
(US, banking, dated) An unsolicited credit card issue.

definitionGroups.group: A decline in degree, quality, quantity, or rate.

entries.meaning: (sewing)
Of men's clothes: the difference between the chest circumference and waist circumference.
Of women's clothes: the difference between the bust circumference and hip circumference.

definitionGroups.group: The distance through which something drops, or falls below a certain level.

entries.meaning: The distance below a cliff or other high position through which someone or something could fall; hence, a steep slope.
examples: On one side of the road was a 50-foot drop.

entries.meaning: The vertical length of a hanging curtain.
(engineering) The distance of the axis of a shaft below the base of a hanger.
(law enforcement) The distance that a person drops when being executed by hanging.
(nautical) The depth of a (square) sail (generally applied to the courses only); the vertical dimension of a sail.
A place where items or supplies may be left for others to collect, whether openly (as with a mail drop), or secretly or illegally (as in crime or espionage); a drop-off point.
examples: I left the plans at the drop, like you asked.

entries.meaning: (informal) Only used in get the drop on, have the drop on An advantage.

(music) A point in a song, usually electronic music such as dubstep, house, trace, or trap, where there is a very noticeable and pleasing change in bass, tempo, and/or overall tone; a climax, a highlight.

description: From Middle English droppen, dropen (“to fall in drops, drip or trickle down; to scatter, sprinkle; to be covered with a liquid; to give off moisture; of an object: to drop, fall; of a living being: to fall to the ground”) [and other forms], from Old English dropian, droppian (“to drop”), from dropa (“a drop”) (see further at etymology 1) + -ian (suffix forming verbs from adjectives and nouns).

verbs.description: drop (third-person singular simple present drops, present participle dropping, simple past and past participle dropped or (archaic) dropt)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) Of a liquid: to fall in drops or droplets. [from 11th c.]
(intransitive, also figuratively) To fall (straight down) under the influence of gravity, like a drop of liquid. [from 14th c.]
examples: A single shot was fired and the bird dropped from the sky.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To fall or sink quickly or suddenly to the ground. [from 15th c.]
examples: Drop and give me thirty push-ups, private!
If your clothes are on fire, stop, drop and roll.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To collapse in exhaustion or injury; also, to fall dead, or to fall in death.
(intransitive) To fall into a particular condition or state.
(intransitive) To come to an end (by not being kept up); to lapse, to stop. [from 17th c.]

definitionGroups.group: (intransitive) To decrease, diminish, or lessen in condition, degree, value, etc. [from 18th c.]

entries.meaning: (intransitive) Of a song or sound: to lower in key, pitch, tempo, or other quality.
examples: My synthesizer makes the notes sound funny when they drop below C2.
The song, 180 beats per minute, drops to 150 BPM near the end.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) Of a voice: to lower in timbre, often due to puberty.
examples: Billy’s voice dropped suddenly when he turned 12.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To fall behind or to the rear of a group of people, etc., as a result of not keeping up with those at the front.
(intransitive) Usually followed by by, in, or into: of a person: to visit someone or somewhere informally or without a prior appointment.
examples: Do drop by soon and I’ll lend you that book.
We’ll drop in on her tomorrow.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, computing, music, television, colloquial) Of a programme, software, a music album or song, etc.: to enter public distribution.
examples: The album Hip-Hop Xmas dropped in time for the holidays.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, gambling) To drop out of the betting.
examples: But more important, if I dropped, Marty would have won the hand automatically.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, physiology, informal) Of the testicles: to hang further away from the body and begin producing sperm due to puberty.
(intransitive, obsolete) To let drops fall; to discharge itself in drops.
(transitive) To drip (a liquid) in drops or small amounts. [from 14th c.]
(transitive, ergative, also figuratively) To let (something) fall; to allow (something) to fall (either by releasing hold of, or losing one's grip on). [from 14th c.]
examples: Don’t drop that plate!    The police ordered the men to drop their weapons.

definitionGroups.group: (transitive) To move to a lower position; to allow to hang downwards; to lower.

entries.meaning: To quickly lower or take down (one's trousers), especially in public.
(cooking) To cook (food, especially fast food), particularly by lowering into hot oil to deep-fry, or by grilling.
examples: Drop a basket of fries.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To reduce; to make smaller.
examples: 2011, Alexander Mamishev, Sean Williams, Technical Writing for Teams: The STREAM Tools Handbook (page 64)

entries.meaning: (transitive) Of an animal (usually a sheep): to give birth to (young); of a bird: to lay (an egg).
examples: to drop a lamb

entries.meaning: (transitive) To mention (something) casually or incidentally, usually in conversation. [from 17th c.]
examples: The lecturer would drop hints whenever the students struggled.
name drop

entries.meaning: (transitive) To let (a letter, etc.) fall into a postbox; hence, to send (a letter, email, or other message) in an offhand manner. [from 18th c.]
examples: As she had a free moment, she dropped her a text.
Drop me a note when you get to the city.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make (someone or something) fall to the ground from a blow, gunshot, etc.; to bring down, to shoot down. [from 18th c.]
examples: Make any sudden movements and I will drop you!

entries.meaning: (transitive) To set down (someone or something) from a vehicle; to stop and deliver or deposit (someone or something); to drop off.
examples: Could you drop me at the airport on your way to work tomorrow?
I’ll be dropping the parcel at your place later.

definitionGroups.group: (transitive) To lower (a sound, a voice, etc.) in pitch or volume.

entries.meaning: (transitive, music) To tune (a guitar string, etc.) to a lower note.
(transitive) To cease concerning oneself over (someone or something); to have nothing more to do with (a discussion, subject, etc.). [from 17th c.]
examples: I’m tired of this subject. Will you just drop it?

entries.meaning: (transitive) To dispose or get rid of (something); to lose, to remove.
examples: I dropped ten pounds and an obnoxious fiancée.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cease to include (something), as if on a list; to dismiss, to eject, to expel.
examples: I’ve been dropped from the football team.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cancel or cease to participate in (a scheduled course, event, or project).
examples: I had to drop calculus because it was taking up too much of my time.

entries.meaning: To lose, spend, or otherwise part with (money). [from 17th c.]
examples: The question was: Who put the most in the collection box? The wealthy guy, who dropped a “C” note, or the tattered old dame who parted with her last tarnished penny.

entries.meaning: To pass or use (counterfeit cheques, money, etc.).
To impart (something).
examples: I drop knowledge wherever I go.

entries.meaning: Especially in drop acid: to swallow (a drug, particularly LSD). [from 20th c.]
(transitive, computing, music, television, colloquial) To release (a programme, software, a music album or song, etc.) to the public.
examples: They dropped the album Hip-Hop Xmas in time for the holidays.
That hacker has been threatening to drop my docs [i.e. publish my personal information].

entries.meaning: (transitive, linguistics) To fail to write, or (especially) to pronounce (a syllable, letter, etc.). [from 19th c.]
examples: Cockneys drop their aitches.

entries.meaning: To play (a portion of music) in the manner of a disc jockey.
examples: I love it when he drops his funky beats.
That guy can drop the bass like a monster.

entries.meaning: To perform (rap music).
examples: Yo, I drop rhymes like nobody’s business.

entries.meaning: (originally US) To (unexpectedly) lose (a competition, game, etc.).
(cricket) Of a fielder: to fail to dismiss (a batsman) by accidentally dropping a batted ball that had initially been caught.
examples: Warne dropped Tendulkar on 99. Tendulkar went on to get a century next ball.

entries.meaning: (rugby) To score (a goal) by means of a drop kick.
(transitive, archaic) To cover (something) with or as if with drops, especially of a different colour; to bedrop, to variegate.
(intransitive, computing) To enter a more basic interface.
examples: drop to a shell

entries.meaning: (transitive, computing) To present the user with a more basic interface.
examples: You are being dropped to a recovery shell.
